G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: This action arises under the laws of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, including but not limited to G.L. c. 186, § 14, which provides tenants a cause of action for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19 and \u00a7 21.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and § 21, the Cambridge District Court has jurisdiction over this matter because the amount in controversy does not exceed the statutory jurisdictional limit of the District Court and because this is an action in contract and under G.L. c. 186, § 14.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2 and G.L. c. 223, \.proposition: Venue is proper in the Cambridge Division of the District Court Department under G.L. c. 223, § 2 and G.L. c. 223, § 8 because the Property and Premises that are the subject of this action are located in Cambridge, Massachusetts, within this Court’s territorial jurisdiction.

Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.raw_text: Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973).
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.proposition: The tenancy between Plaintiff and Defendant is subject to, and incorporates by operation of law, the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment set forth in G.L. c. 186, § 14, and the implied warranty of habitability recognized in Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973).
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.support_reasoning: This separate opinion agrees that Massachusetts should abandon caveat emptor in residential leases and that statutes and codes become part of the landlord–tenant relationship by operation of law. Justice Quirico would ground the new rule in an implied agreement that the premises comply with statutory and code standards, and he explicitly recognizes that G.L. c. 111 and the State Sanitary Code impose obligations on landlords for tenants’ benefit. Although he criticizes the majority’s broader "implied warranty of habitability" formulation, his concurrence/dissent accepts that tenancies incorporate statutory minimum standards (including quiet enjoyment‑type protections) by operation of law; the majority in Hemingway (not quoted here) actually adopts the implied warranty of habitability. Thus, the case as a whole supports the proposition that residential tenancies are subject to a statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment and an implied warranty of habitability, though this excerpt itself partly argues for a narrower statutory‑based theory.
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.relevant_excerpt: As the first step in the removal of the roadblock discussed above I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards, and (b) that by renting such a unit the landlord impliedly agrees with his tenant (i) that at the time of the renting the unit complies with those standards and (ii) that during the term of the renting he will do whatever such legal provisions require him to do for compliance with such standards.

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every residential lease includes an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment protecting the tenant from serious interference with the use and enjoyment of the leased premises caused by the landlord or those acting under his authority.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states that G.L. c. 186, § 14 codified the tenant’s common-law rights under the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment and explains the standard for landlord liability under that covenant. It further clarifies that liability arises where the landlord, through at least negligent conduct, directly or indirectly interferes with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment, typically by failing to correct known defects. This aligns with the proposition that Massachusetts residential leases include an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment protecting tenants from serious landlord-caused interference.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 186, § 14, originally enacted in 1927, codified a tenant’s common law rights under the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment. St. 1927, c. 339, § 1. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 101-102 (1982). At common law, and as originally enacted by statute, the covenant of quiet enjoyment prohibited a landlord from wilful or intentional interference with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the leased premises. In 1973, the statute was rewritten and the requirement of intentional conduct was eliminated; landlords could now be held liable for ‘directly or indirectly’ interfering with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.”

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715\.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every residential lease includes an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment protecting the tenant from serious interference with the use and enjoyment of the leased premises caused by the landlord or those acting under his authority.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715\.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses the scope of the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment in Massachusetts residential leases and holds that it can be violated by serious interference with tenants’ use and enjoyment caused by activities of others where the landlord created the situation and had the right to control the conditions. The court expressly treats quiet enjoyment as an implied covenant, focuses on substantial deprivation of quiet enjoyment, and rejects any requirement of subjective intent, instead tying breach to the natural and probable consequences of what the landlord did, failed to do, or permitted to be done by those acting under his authority (here, the lounge tenants).
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715\.relevant_excerpt: “He ruled that the tenants’ implied warranty of quiet enjoyment was violated by late evening and early morning music and disturbances coming from nearby premises which the landlords leased to others for use as a bar or cocktail lounge…. There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.”

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 285–86 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: Massachusetts courts have held that excessive noise and disturbances originating from activities under the landlord’s control may constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The court squarely holds that a landlord’s failure to take reasonable measures to control third-party misconduct in common areas under its control can breach the covenant of quiet enjoyment. The opinion explains that if the landlord permits unlawful activity and resulting disturbances in those areas, causing serious interference with tenants’ use of the premises, that may constitute a violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14. This fits the proposition that excessive disturbances originating from activities under the landlord’s control may breach quiet enjoyment.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy… If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.” (417 Mass. at 284–87)

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.proposition: Plaintiff reserves the right to seek the full relief allowed under G.L. c. 186, § 14, including but not limited to actual and consequential damages and, if shown to be applicable, statutory minimum damages of three months’ rent.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion directly interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14, holding that a landlord who interferes with quiet enjoyment is liable for “actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater,” and discusses both actual/consequential damages and the statutory three‑months’ rent alternative. It also clarifies that emotional distress and other personal injuries are within “actual and consequential” damages. Thus, the case supports the proposition that a plaintiff may seek full relief under § 14, including actual and consequential damages and, where applicable, the statutory minimum of three months’ rent.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord that violates § 14 is subject to a fine or imprisonment, and is liable to its tenants for ‘actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater,’ plus costs and attorneys’ fees. … Section 14 provides that tenants may recover ‘actual and consequential’ damages from landlords who have interfered with their quiet enjoyment of leased premises. … The combination in § 14 of both actual and consequential damages, therefore, suggests that the Legislature intended to include all reasonably foreseeable losses — personal as well as economic — within the scope of statutory recovery.”

Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.raw_text: Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761–62 (1979).
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.proposition: Plaintiff reserves the right to seek the full relief allowed under G.L. c. 186, § 14, including but not limited to actual and consequential damages and, if shown to be applicable, statutory minimum damages of three months’ rent.
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion directly interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14, explaining that a lessor who interferes with quiet enjoyment is liable for “actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater,” and that the three‑months’ rent figure operates as a statutory minimum when actual damages are slight or hard to prove. That aligns with the proposition that a plaintiff may seek full relief under § 14, including actual and consequential damages and, where applicable, the statutory minimum of three months’ rent. The case constrains multiplicative use of the three‑month minimum but affirms its availability as part of the remedial scheme described in the proposition.
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “Section 14 provides that a lessor who commits any act in violation of that section (including interference ‘with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises’) shall ‘be liable for actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, and the costs of the action, including a reasonable attorney’s fee.’ … Section 14 allows a minimum recovery of three months’ rent as an incentive to the pursuit of relief where the actual and consequential damages are slight or are difficult to prove. When the actual damages exceed three months’ rent, however, § 14 plainly states that actual damages should be the measure of recovery.”

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982, 983 (1982).
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landlord may be held liable for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment where his actions create conditions resulting in continuous or repeated interference with tenants’ premises, including excessive noise or disturbances emanating from another part of the property under the landlord’s control.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The opinion does affirm that a landlord’s actions that substantially impair the value of the leased premises can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, and cites Blackett v. Olanoff (a noise/disturbance case) as general authority. However, Lowery itself deals only with failure to provide heat—there is no discussion of excessive noise or disturbances from other parts of the property—so it does not itself establish or apply the specific rule about noise or disturbances alleged in the proposition.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season…seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’…and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See generally Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715-716 (1977), and cases cited. It is not necessary to recovery that the landlord intended to violate the covenant. Rather ‘the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.’…liability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’”

Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.raw_text: Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782, 788–89 (1994).
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, Plaintiff is entitled to recover her actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, plus costs and reasonable attorneys’ fees, as applicable.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.support_reasoning: The opinion directly quotes G.L. c. 186, § 14 and describes the damages available as “actual and consequential damages or three month’s rent, whichever is greater, and the costs of the action, including a reasonable attorney’s fee.” The court then applies § 14 to hold that Thomas is entitled to reasonable attorney’s fees upon establishing a violation. This matches the proposition that a plaintiff may recover actual/consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, plus costs and reasonable attorneys’ fees under § 14.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.relevant_excerpt: General Laws c. 186, § 14 (1992 ed.), provides, in pertinent part, that “any lessor or landlord who directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant . . . shall ... be liable for actual and consequential damages or three month’s rent, whichever is greater, and the costs of the action, including a reasonable attorney’s fee.” … On remand, Thomas is entitled to reasonable attorney’s fees on this basis.

G.L. c. 93A, \u00a7\u00a7 2 and 9.proposition: To the extent necessary, Plaintiff invokes the remedial protections of G.L. c. 93A, §§ 2 and 9 only insofar as they inform the interpretation and enforcement of landlords’ duties to tenants under Massachusetts law, including recognition that unfair or deceptive practices in the landlord–tenant context are disfavored.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Pre-judgment and post-judgment interest as allowed by law, including under G.L. c. 231, § 6B;
